sen.j: 四職（ししき/ししょく）は、室町時代の武家の家格。
sen.e: The Shishiki represents the ranking or social status of samurai families in the Muromachi Period.

sen.j: 室町幕府の軍事指揮と京都市中の警察・徴税等を司る侍所の長官（頭人、所司）に交代で任じられた守護大名の赤松氏、一色氏、京極氏、山名氏の4氏を指して「四職」と称する。
sen.e: The Chokan (supervisor) (Tonin (頭人) and Shoshi (所司)) of the Samurai-dokoro (Board of Retainers) were responsible for controlling the military forces of the Muromachi Bakufu (shogunate) and the police and tax levy within Kyoto City, and the Akamatsu clan, the Isshiki clan, the Kyogoku clan and the Yamana clan as shugo daimyo (feudal lord owning a territory) were assigned to serve as the Chokan of the Samurai-dokoro in turn, and are referred to as the Shishiki or Shishoku.

The Chokan (supervisor) (Tonin (頭人) and Shoshi (所司)) of the Samurai-dokoro (Board of Retainers) were responsible for controlling the military forces of the Muromachi Bakufu (shogunate) and the police and tax levy within Kyoto City, and the Akamatsu, Isshiki, Kyogoku and Yamana clans as shugo daimyo (feudal lords owning land) were assigned to serve as the Chokan of the Samurai-dokoro in turn, and are referred to as the Shishiki or Shishoku.

The Akamatsu, Isshiki, Kyogoku and Yamana clans, whose heads were feudal lords that ruled local territories as military governors, were known as the "Shishiki (or Shishoku)" clans (meaning "four top ranking clans") and the military police director (called "tonin" or "shoshi" in Japanese) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was chosen from among these clans in turn in order to take charge of military leadership, law enforcement and tax collection in the city of Kyoto.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。統一事項より、Muromachi shogunate government→Muromachi bakufuとし、初出のためbakufuの補足追加

sen.j: ただし、実際はこの4家と並んで美濃国守護・土岐氏もしばしば侍所頭人に任じられており、これも含むのが相当であろう。
sen.e: However, the Toki clan as shugo (守護, local government post determined by the bakufu) in the Province of Mino was repeatedly assigned to the Tonin of the Samurai-dokoro as well as the four clans, so it will be appropriate to add the Toki clan to the Shishiki.

However, the Toki clan as shugo (守護, local government post determined by the bakufu) in the Province of Mino was repeatedly assigned to the Tonin of the Samurai-dokoro as well as the four clans, so it is appropriate to add the Toki clan to the Shishiki.

In fact, however, the military police director was often also chosen from the Toki clan, a ruling clan in Mino Province, along with these four clans, which therefore needs to be included as a "Shishiki" clan.

sen.j: 三管領家（細川氏、斯波氏、畠山氏）と並び幕府の宿老として中央政治に参与した。
sen.e: In the position of Shukuro (an important retainer) of the bakufu, the Shishiki participated in the politics conducted by the bakufu as central governement as well as the three Kanrei (a government post) families (the Hosokawa clan, the Shiba clan and the Hatakeyama clan.)

In the position of Shukuro (an important retainer) of the bakufu, the Shishiki participated in the politics conducted by the bakufu as central government as well as the three Kanrei (a government post) families (Hosokawa clan, Shiba clan and Hatakeyama clan)

Members of the Shishiki clans participated in political affairs of the Muromachi government as principal retainers of the bakufu along with the three clans (Hosokawa, Shiba and Hatakeyama clans) from which shugun's deputies were chosen.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。shogunate→bakufuとしました。

sen.j: 応仁の乱以降、赤松政則などが就任する場合もあったが、畿内の争乱や守護の在国化等のため空席となり自然消滅した。
sen.e: After the Ounin no Ran (Onin War), Masanori AKAMATSU and others were assigned for the post, but it gradually became vacant because of battles or disturbances in the Kidai (five states close to Kyoto) and constant stay of shugo in their territories, resulting in the natural disappearance of the Shishiki.

After the Ounin no Ran (Onin War), Masanori AKAMATSU and others were assigned to the post, but it gradually became vacant because of battles or disturbances in the Kidai (five states close to Kyoto) and due to the shugo remaining in their territories, resulting in the natural disappearance of the Shishiki.

After the Onin War in 1467, several feudal lords, including Masanori AKAMATSU, were appointed as the military police director, but the post remained vacant for a long period of time and gradually disappeared from history as a result of battles in the Kinai region (areas around Kyoto) and the feudalization of land by powerful feudal rulers.
